title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement mbeck@tbep.org. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to slrcsap
text: outlines propose change slrcsap. detailed discussion contributing packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to slrcsap
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to slrcsap
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to slrcsap
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("tbep-tech/slrcsap", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to slrcsap
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to slrcsap

title: Getting started
text: Install package r-universe follows. source code available GitHub. Load package R session installation:
code: # Install slrcsap in R: install.packages('slrcsap', repos = c('https://tbep-tech.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org')) library(slrcsap)

title: Getting started
text: package includes two core workflows download plot data relevant assess sea level rise risks Tampa Bay region. first workflow retrieves plots historical sea level data second retrieves plots sea level rise scenario data. Default arguments functions set tidal gauge St. Petersburg, FL following recommendations Tampa Bay Climate Science Advisory Panel [1]. content demonstrates use functions package workflow.

title: Getting started
text: Sea level data downloaded NOAA Tides Currents website. data available NOAA tide gauges setup download data St. Petersburg, FL gauge (NOAA ID 8726520) default. data read directly R URL https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/data/8726520_meantrend.txt. data St. Petersburg, includes monthly mean sea level (MSL) values 1947 present, including seasonal correction. Data alternative stations can obtained using gauge argument. sea level data can plotted using plot_sealevel() function.   Various arguments plot_sealevel() can change appearance plot. , color, units, x-axis range modified  plot also ggplot() object can modified additional ggplot2 functions. , plot modified add title change theme.  Lastly, plot can also returned plotly object using plotly = T.
code: # Download sea level data for St. Petersburg spsealevel <- get_sealevel() head(spsealevel) #>     gauge Year Month       date  msl_m     msl_ft #> 1 8726520 1947     1 1947-01-01 -0.063 -0.2066929 #> 2 8726520 1947     2 1947-02-01 -0.132 -0.4330709 #> 3 8726520 1947     3 1947-03-01 -0.142 -0.4658793 #> 4 8726520 1947     4 1947-04-01 -0.150 -0.4921260 #> 5 8726520 1947     5 1947-05-01 -0.086 -0.2821522 #> 6 8726520 1947     6 1947-06-01 -0.064 -0.2099738 # Download sea level data for Cedar Key cksealevel <- get_sealevel(gauge = 8727520) head(cksealevel) #>     gauge Year Month       date  msl_m     msl_ft #> 1 8727520 1914     4 1914-04-01 -0.170 -0.5577428 #> 2 8727520 1914     5 1914-05-01 -0.161 -0.5282152 #> 3 8727520 1914     6 1914-06-01 -0.142 -0.4658793 #> 4 8727520 1914     7 1914-07-01 -0.129 -0.4232284 #> 5 8727520 1914     8 1914-08-01 -0.098 -0.3215223 #> 6 8727520 1914     9 1914-09-01 -0.186 -0.6102362 # Plot sea level data for St. Petersburg plot_sealevel(spsealevel) # Plot sea level data for Cedar Key plot_sealevel(cksealevel) # Change arguments for the plot plot_sealevel(spsealevel, col = 'tomato1', units = 'm',                xrng = as.Date(c('2000-01-01', '2023-01-01'))) # Add a title and change the theme library(ggplot2) plot_sealevel(spsealevel) +   ggtitle('Monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) at St. Petersburg, FL') +   theme_grey() # Create plotly output plot_sealevel(spsealevel, plotly = T)

title: Getting started
text: Sea level rise scenarios can downloaded using get_scenario() function. Data downloaded Interagency Sea Level Rise Scenario Tool website uses regionally corrected NOAA 2022 curves. Details methods used tool found technical report [2]. data downloaded Excel sheet URL https://sealevel.nasa.gov/task-force-scenario-tool?psmsl_id=520, set St. Petersburg, FL default. Emissions scenarios NOAA Intermediate Low, Intermediate, Intermediate High downloaded default, recommended Climate Science Advisory Panel. data show relative sea level change (RSLC) 2020 2150 scenario meters feet. Data alternative locations scenarios can obtained using id scenario arguments, respectively. sea level rise scenarios can plotted using plot_scenario() function. Note default x-axis range extends 2100.   Various arguments plot_scenario() can change appearance plot. , color ramp, units, x-axis range modified  plot also ggplot() object can modified additional ggplot2 functions. , plot modified add title, subtitle, change theme.  Lastly, plot can also returned plotly object using plotly = T.
code: # Download sea level rise scenarios for St. Petersburg spscenario <- get_scenario() head(spscenario) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id scenario               year slr_m slr_ft #>   <dbl> <fct>                 <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2020 0.113  0.372 #> 2   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2030 0.180  0.592 #> 3   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2040 0.250  0.821 #> 4   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2050 0.322  1.06  #> 5   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2060 0.392  1.29  #> 6   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2070 0.463  1.52 # Download sea level rise scenarios for Cedar Key ckscenario <- get_scenario(id = 428, scenario = c('Low', 'IntLow', 'Int', 'IntHigh', 'High')) head(ckscenario) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id scenario  year slr_m slr_ft #>   <dbl> <fct>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1   428 NOAA Low  2020 0.101  0.332 #> 2   428 NOAA Low  2030 0.153  0.502 #> 3   428 NOAA Low  2040 0.207  0.679 #> 4   428 NOAA Low  2050 0.258  0.847 #> 5   428 NOAA Low  2060 0.301  0.988 #> 6   428 NOAA Low  2070 0.340  1.12 # Plot sea level rise scenarios for St. Petersburg plot_scenario(spscenario) # Plot sea level rise scenarios for Cedar Key plot_scenario(ckscenario) # Change arguments for the plot plot_scenario(spscenario, cols = c('green', 'blue', 'red'), units = 'm',                xrng = c(2020, 2150)) # Add a title, subtitle and change the theme plot_scenario(spscenario) +   labs(     title = 'Relative Sea Level Change Projections',     subtitle = 'Gauge 8726520, St. Petersburg, FL'   ) +   theme_grey() +    theme(legend.position = 'bottom') # Create plotly output plot_scenario(spscenario, plotly = T)

what: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
code: get_scenario(   id = 520,   scenario = c("IntLow", "Int", "IntHigh"),   method = "curl",   quiet = TRUE )

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: id numeric, gauge number. Default 520 (St. Petersburg, FL). scenario character, SLR scenario. Default 'IntLow', 'Int', 'IntHigh' (NOAA Intermediate Low, Intermediate, Intermediate High). See details available options. method character, download method. Default 'curl', passed download.file(). quiet logical, suppress download messages. Default TRUE.

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: data frame columns id, scenario, year, SLR meters, SLR feet.

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: Information https://sealevel.nasa.gov/task-force-scenario-tool?psmsl_id=520, default. Results SLR meters feet intermediate low, intermediate, intermediate high scenarios based recommended scenarios Climate Science Advisory Panel.  Full options scenarios 'Low', 'IntLow', 'Int', 'IntHigh', 'High'. Values SLR relative change 2020.

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
code: dat <- get_scenario() head(dat) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id scenario               year slr_m slr_ft #>   <dbl> <fct>                 <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2020 0.113  0.372 #> 2   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2030 0.180  0.592 #> 3   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2040 0.250  0.821 #> 4   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2050 0.322  1.06  #> 5   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2060 0.392  1.29  #> 6   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2070 0.463  1.52

title: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
text: Information https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov using URL https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/data/8726520_meantrend.txt, default.  Results monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) meters feet, seasonal cycle removed.

what: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
text: Plot sea level scenario data

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
code: plot_scenario(   dat,   cols = c("deepskyblue", "orange", "red"),   units = "ft",   linewidth = 1,   caption = TRUE,   xrng = c(2020, 2100),   xbrk = 10,   yrng = NULL,   ybrk = 7,   plotly = FALSE )

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
text: dat Input data get_scenario(). cols character, color palette lines. Default c('deepskyblue', 'orange', 'red'). units character, units y-axis. Default 'ft'. Options 'ft' 'm'. linewidth numeric, line width. Default 1. caption logical, add caption source. Default TRUE. apply plotly = TRUE. xrng numeric, x-axis range. Default c(2020, 2100). xbrk numeric, number x-axis breaks. Default 10. apply plotly = TRUE. yrng numeric, y-axis range two values. Default NULL, uses range data. ybrk numeric, number y-axis breaks. Default 7. apply plotly = TRUE. plotly logical, TRUE, returns plotly object instead ggplot. Default FALSE.

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
text: ggplot object

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
text: Plot sea level data

title: Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
code: plot_sealevel(   dat,   col = "deepskyblue",   units = "ft",   caption = TRUE,   xrng = NULL,   xbrk = 10,   yrng = NULL,   ybrk = 5,   plotly = FALSE )

title: Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
text: dat Input data get_sealevel(). col character, color line. Default 'deepskyblue'. units character, units y-axis. Default 'ft'. Options 'ft' 'm'. caption logical, add caption source. Default TRUE. apply plotly = TRUE. xrng Date, x-axis range two values. Default NULL, uses range data. xbrk numeric, number x-axis breaks. Default 10. apply plotly = TRUE. yrng numeric, y-axis range two values. Default NULL, uses range data. ybrk numeric, number y-axis breaks. Default 5. apply plotly = TRUE. plotly logical, TRUE, returns plotly object instead ggplot. Default FALSE.
